comments.raw_text:
The animations for indeterminate <progress> elements are handled entirely through the native widget code, with no CSS-based fallback in forms.css.  This means that if an author overrides the style of a <progress> element (e.g., custom background color), it disables the native widget rendering and the indeterminate progress bar is then shown as just a static 100% full progress bar with no indication to the user that it is "working" in an indeterminate state.

An author should not be expected to code up animation CSS just so that he can, for example, override some colors.

However, CSS animations currently cannot be applied to the internal bar element (bug 665364), so that will need to be addressed first...

comments.text:
Created attachment 541140
"pulse" the background color [does not work properly]

This is what I meant in comment 2: hide the internal bar, and cycle the the background color of the progress element itself to give it a pulsing effect.

While this avoids the bug 662351 dependency, it runs into another problem: HasAuthorSpecifiedRules treats the background color in the animation as an author rule instead of an agent rule because @keyframes are treated separately in the cascade and fall under eAnimationSheet instead of eAgentSheet, etc.

I'm not familiar with the style code, but it seems to me that it would make more sense if HasAuthorSpecifiedRules used the rule level of the rule that referenced the @keyframes instead (I'm guessing that, like bug 662351, that will be non-trivial as well?)...
